Jul 25 10:40:20 yes it is working now :) Jul 25 10:40:21 * redramires (~brabo@225-237-135-95.pool.ukrtel.net) has joined #dgplug Jul 25 10:40:25 rahulch: good :) Jul 25 10:40:32 * cha1tanya has quit (Quit: cha1tanya) Jul 25 10:40:45 * kenzo450D has quit (Ping timeout: 268 seconds) Jul 25 10:41:00 so this if __name__ == '__main__' Jul 25 10:41:13 it runs whatever is inside if this code is run as script Jul 25 10:41:22 exactly Jul 25 10:41:43 which is useful as it prevents codes to be run if the file is imported into another file Jul 25 10:41:53 so just to be clear Jul 25 10:42:04 * anuragk_ has quit (Client Quit) Jul 25 10:42:14 you know you can write some code into a file and run it via python .py Jul 25 10:42:28 * anuragk (~anurag@202.142.124.167) has joined #dgplug Jul 25 10:42:36 you can also import in a file code from another file Jul 25 10:43:10 that's pretty much what does the import and from import Jul 25 10:43:47 but if you have a file test.py that contains "print('hello')" and have a second file test2.py with an import test Jul 25 10:43:53 the print will be run at import Jul 25 10:44:09 (which is not what's desired most of the time) Jul 25 10:44:53 so having "if __name__ == '__main__': print('hello')" makes sure that the print is only executed if the file is directly run from python Jul 25 10:45:39 * nshaikh (nshaikh@nat/redhat/x-efkrsrkqvqerrqwo) has left #dgplug ("Leaving") Jul 25 10:45:46 * elita15__ (0e8bdd12@gateway/web/freenode/ip.14.139.221.18) has joined #dgplug Jul 25 10:45:48 personally I use this construct quite often when I want to test a module, just put it at the bottom of the file and have it call one of the function you wrote to test/debug it Jul 25 10:46:23 do you see the interest of "if __name__ == '__main__'"?
